STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 30, 2022
Ashley Donahue
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Muskegon
1720 Park Street
Muskegon, MI 49441
RE: License #: CB610201023
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Muskegon
1720 Park Street
Muskegon, MI 49441
Dear Ms. Donahue:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on June 29,
2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(517) 284-9740
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12404 Placement
(7) An agency shall document, in the child’s record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(h) A photograph of the child at the time of placement.
One of eight open foster care files reviewed did not contain a photograph of the youth
as required.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the Updated Service Plan/Initial
Service Plan completed timely.
File one: ISP not completed timely; report due 10/6/2021 and was submitted on
10/29/2021.
File two: USP not completed timely, report due 3/21/2022 and was submitted on
3/22/2022.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.16 Supervisory oversight
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload.
One of eight open foster care files reviewed did have documented monthly
supervision with staff as required.
4

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case
service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/28/2021 (cited under FOM 722-08)
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Four of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on
the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
File one: 7/28/2021 PATP does not show mother or foster parent signature,
10/25/2021 and 1/23/2022 PATP is signed by foster parent but not dated.
File two: 4/4/2022 mother’s PATP not uploaded, unable to verify signature.
File three: 4/26/2022 PATP not uploaded so unable to verify signatures.
File four: 11/18/2021 PATP father signature not obtained timely (6/3/2022), 1/13/2022
PATP Foster parent signature not obtained timely (6/3/2022), 4/11/2022 PATP father
and Foster parent signature not obtained timely (6/3/2022).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/28/2021
7/14/2020 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/3/2020
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
5

Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include reunification,
placement in a residential setting, step-down from a residential or
hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request for change in
foster home/relative placements.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.
File one: There is no corresponding FTM for 5/30/2022 USP.
File two: There is no corresponding FTM for 1/4/2022 USP.
File three: There is no corresponding FTM for 6/17/2022 USP or 9/7/2021 placement
change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/28/2021
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Six of eight foster care files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the
DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/28/2021
7/14/2020 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/3/2020
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
An updated medical passport is provided to:
6

 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
 All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child
is newly referred to and accepted for treatment and/or
services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment while
the foster care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
 Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth age 16
and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults age
18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Three of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
File one: Initial medical passport was not provided within 14 days of removal; child
was removed on 9/7/2021 and medical passport provided to foster parent on
10/28/2021.
File two: Initial medical passport was not provided within 14 days. Child was placed
with grandmother on 9/7/2021 and medical passport was provided on 10/5/2021
File three: Child was removed on 4/1/2022 and there is not an initial medial passport.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 7/28/2021
7/14/2020 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/3/2020
7

FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been found
to produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A quality
visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:
 Can meet with each child individually, without the presence of
other individuals, to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions as well as discuss the current placement.
 Views the child's bedroom and sleeping arrangements.
 Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for infants
under 12 months.
 Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental, mental
health and other needs and takes appropriate action or offers
services in response to the identified needs of each child.
 Shows interest in the child to build and establish rapport.
 Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan for
parenting time, visits with siblings and other relatives, and the
child's permanency plan, in a developmentally appropriate
way while allowing the child to ask questions and express
viewpoints.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation of a quality visit.
File one: 3/18/2022 & 3/22/2022 home visits do not document a quality visit was
conducted.
File two: 4/6/2022 & 4/22/2022 home visits do not document a quality visit was
conducted.
ADM 330 Quarterly adoption progress reports
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report. The
adoption worker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child during each quarter prior to the adoption
supervision period for the purpose of completing the DHS-
614. The child adoption assessment may serve as the initial
quarterly report if it is completed within the required quarterly
reporting period and attached to the DHS-614 form.
8

Two of six adoption files reviewed contained quarterly progress reports that were not
completed timely.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Make sure PATP signatures are dated.
 Upload renewal letters to verify application was sent timely.
 Consider utilizing home visit checklist and structured contacts for face-to-face
visits to ensure quality visits are documented.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 7/2/2021 with a corrective action plan approved on
7/28/2021. During the review the agency had thirteen violations. Five citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under review
the agency expressed the impact that the COVID-19 pandemic had on overall
compliance. In addition, the agency noted that they have hired several new staff
during the review period, and they feel that also impacted overall compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator stated the previous year CAP was effective due processes
being put in place that the agency feels reduced the number of citations, specifically
in licensing. The Chief Administrator assessment reported ongoing challenges related
to COVID-19 have impacted overall compliance with licensing rules and policy. In
addition, the agency has experienced growth and hired several new staff.
The Chief Administrator indicated ongoing training and support for staff and
supervisors has been a focus of the agency. Additional oversight, development of
CAP driven inter-office policies and procedures, and implementation of checklists
have had a positive impact. The agency hired a Compliance Officer to assist with
overall compliance. The Chief Administrator expressed confidence that several areas
will improve over the next review period.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff did not identify any
areas the agency could improve. Staff reported the agency communicates changes
and updates timely and efficiently. In addition, the weekly team meetings are helpful.
9

Staff reported feeling supported by supervisors and co-workers and reported no areas
of need.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
___________6/30/2022___________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 30, 2022
______________________________________________________________ _
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
